			<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Fundamental analysis</span></h1>
			<!-- /firstHeading -->
			<!-- bodyContent -->
			<div id="bodyContent">

<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;">
<div class="noprint plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Financial_markets" title="Template:Financial markets"><span title="View this template" style="">v</span></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Financial_markets" title="Template talk:Financial markets"><span title="Discuss this template" style="">t</span></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Financial_markets&amp;action=edit"><span title="Edit this template" style="">e</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><b>Fundamental analysis</b> of a business involves analyzing its <a href="/wiki/Financial_statement" title="Financial statement">financial statements</a> and health, its management and competitive advantages, and its <a href="/wiki/Competition" title="Competition">competitors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Market" title="Market">markets</a>. When applied to <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">forex</a>, it focuses on the overall state of the economy, interest rates, production, earnings, and management. When analyzing a stock, futures contract, or currency using fundamental analysis there are two basic approaches one can use; bottom up analysis and top down analysis.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> The term is used to distinguish such analysis from other types of <a href="/wiki/Investment_analysis" title="Investment analysis" class="mw-redirect">investment analysis</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Quantitative_analysis_(finance)" title="Quantitative analysis (finance)" class="mw-redirect">quantitative analysis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Technical_analysis" title="Technical analysis">technical analysis</a>.</p>
<p>Fundamental analysis is performed on historical and present data, but with the goal of making financial <a href="/wiki/Forecasts" title="Forecasts" class="mw-redirect">forecasts</a>. There are several possible objectives:</p>
<ul>
<li>to conduct a company <a href="/wiki/Stock_valuation" title="Stock valuation">stock valuation</a> and predict its probable price evolution,</li>
<li>to make a projection on its business performance,</li>
<li>to evaluate its management and make internal business decisions,</li>
<li>to calculate its <a href="/wiki/Credit_risk" title="Credit risk">credit risk</a>.</li>
</ul>
<table id="toc" class="toc">
<tr>
<td>
<div id="toctitle">
<h2>Contents</h2>
</div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Two_analytical_models"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Two analytical models</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Use_by_different_portfolio_styles"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Use by different portfolio styles</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Top-down_and_bottom-up"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Top-down and bottom-up</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Procedures"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Procedures</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Criticisms"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Criticisms</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Two_analytical_models">Two analytical models</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Two analytical models">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<p>When the objective of the analysis is to determine what stock to buy and at what price, there are two basic methodologies</p>
<ol>
<li>Fundamental analysis maintains that markets may misprice a security in the short run but that the "correct" price will eventually be reached. <a href="/wiki/Profit_(accounting)" title="Profit (accounting)">Profits</a> can be made by purchasing the mispriced security and then waiting for the market to recognize its "mistake" and reprice the security.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Technical_analysis" title="Technical analysis">Technical analysis</a> maintains that all information is reflected already in the stock price. Trends 'are your friend' and sentiment changes predate and predict trend changes. Investors' emotional responses to price movements lead to recognizable price chart patterns. Technical analysis does not care what the 'value' of a stock is. Their price predictions are only extrapolations from historical price patterns.</li>
</ol>
<p>Investors can use any or all of these different but somewhat complementary methods for stock picking. For example many fundamental investors use technicals for deciding entry and exit points. Many technical investors use fundamentals to limit their universe of possible stock to 'good' companies.</p>
<p>The choice of stock analysis is determined by the investor's belief in the different paradigms for "how the stock market works". See the discussions at <a href="/wiki/Efficient-market_hypothesis" title="Efficient-market hypothesis">efficient-market hypothesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Random_walk_hypothesis" title="Random walk hypothesis">random walk hypothesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capital_asset_pricing_model" title="Capital asset pricing model">capital asset pricing model</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fed_model" title="Fed model">Fed model</a> Theory of Equity Valuation, <a href="/wiki/Market-based_valuation" title="Market-based valuation">market-based valuation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Behavioral_finance" title="Behavioral finance" class="mw-redirect">behavioral finance</a>.</p>
<p>Fundamental analysis includes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Economic analysis</li>
<li>Industry analysis</li>
<li>Company analysis</li>
</ol>
<p>On the basis of these three analyses the intrinsic value of the shares are determined. This is considered as the true value of the share. If the intrinsic value is higher than the market price it is recommended to buy the share . If it is equal to market price hold the share and if it is less than the market price sell the shares.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Use_by_different_portfolio_styles">Use by different portfolio styles</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Use by different portfolio styles">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<p>Investors may use fundamental analysis within different <a href="/wiki/Portfolio_(finance)" title="Portfolio (finance)">portfolio</a> <a href="/wiki/Investment_management" title="Investment management">management</a> <a href="/wiki/Investor_profile" title="Investor profile">styles</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Buy_and_hold" title="Buy and hold">Buy and hold</a></b> investors believe that latching onto good businesses allows the investor's asset to grow with the business. Fundamental analysis lets them find 'good' companies, so they lower their risk and probability of wipe-out.</li>
<li>Managers may use fundamental analysis to correctly value 'good' and 'bad' companies. Eventually 'bad' companies' stock goes up and down, creating opportunities for profits.</li>
<li>Managers may also consider the economic cycle in determining whether conditions are 'right' to buy fundamentally suitable companies.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Contrarian" title="Contrarian">Contrarian</a> investors</b> distinguish "in the short run, the market is a voting machine, not a weighing machine".<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> Fundamental analysis allows you to make your own decision on value, and ignore the market.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Value_investing" title="Value investing">Value investors</a></b> restrict their attention to under-valued companies, believing that 'it's hard to fall out of a ditch'. The value comes from fundamental analysis.</li>
<li>Managers may use fundamental analysis to determine future growth rates for buying high priced <a href="/wiki/Growth_stock" title="Growth stock">growth stocks</a>.</li>
<li>Managers may also include fundamental factors along with technical factors into computer models (<a href="/wiki/Quantitative_analysis_(finance)" title="Quantitative analysis (finance)" class="mw-redirect">quantitative analysis</a>).</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Top-down_and_bottom-up">Top-down and bottom-up</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Top-down and bottom-up">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<p>Investors can use either a top-down or bottom-up approach.</p>
<ul>
<li>The top-down investor starts his or her analysis with global economics, including both international and national <a href="/wiki/Economic_indicator" title="Economic indicator">economic indicators</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP" class="mw-redirect">GDP</a> growth rates, <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Interest" title="Interest">interest</a> rates, <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Productivity_(economics)" title="Productivity (economics)" class="mw-redirect">productivity</a>, and energy prices. He or she narrows his or her search down to regional/industry analysis of total sales, price levels, the effects of competing products, foreign competition, and entry or exit from the industry. Only then does he or she narrow his or her search to the best business in that area.</li>
<li>The bottom-up investor starts with specific businesses, regardless of their industry/region.</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Procedures">Procedures</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Procedures">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<p>The analysis of a business' health starts with financial statement analysis that includes <a href="/wiki/Financial_ratio" title="Financial ratio">ratios</a>. It looks at dividends paid, operating cash flow, new equity issues and capital financing. The earnings estimates and growth rate projections published widely by <a href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters" title="Thomson Reuters">Thomson Reuters</a> and others can be considered either 'fundamental' (they are facts) or 'technical' (they are investor sentiment) based on your perception of their validity.</p>
<p>The determined growth rates (of income and cash) and risk levels (to determine the <a href="/wiki/Discount_rate" title="Discount rate">discount rate</a>) are used in various valuation models. The foremost is the <a href="/wiki/Discounted_cash_flow" title="Discounted cash flow">discounted cash flow</a> model, which calculates the present value of the future</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dividend" title="Dividend">dividends</a> received by the investor, along with the eventual sale price. (<a href="/wiki/Gordon_model" title="Gordon model" class="mw-redirect">Gordon model</a>)</li>
<li>earnings of the company, or</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cash_flow" title="Cash flow">cash flows</a> of the company.</li>
</ul>
<p>The amount of debt is also a major consideration in determining a company's health. It can be quickly assessed using the <a href="/wiki/Debt-to-equity_ratio" title="Debt-to-equity ratio">debt-to-equity ratio</a> and the <i>current ratio</i> (current assets/current liabilities).</p>
<p>The simple model commonly used is the <a href="/wiki/P/E_ratio" title="P/E ratio" class="mw-redirect">Price/Earnings</a> ratio. Implicit in this model of a perpetual annuity (<a href="/wiki/Time_value_of_money" title="Time value of money">Time value of money</a>) is that the 'flip' of the P/E is the discount rate appropriate to the risk of the business. The multiple accepted is adjusted for expected growth (that is not built into the model).</p>
<p>Growth estimates are incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/PEG_ratio" title="PEG ratio">PEG ratio</a>, but the math does not hold up to analysis.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Its validity depends on the length of time you think the growth will continue. IGAR models can be used to impute expected changes in growth from current P/E and historical growth rates for the stocks relative to a comparison index.</p>
<p>Computer modelling of stock prices has now replaced much of the subjective interpretation of fundamental data (along with technical data) in the industry. Since about year 2000, with the power of computers to crunch vast quantities of data, a new career has been invented. At some funds (called Quant Funds) the manager's decisions have been replaced by proprietary mathematical models.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticisms">Criticisms</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Criticisms">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<ul>
<li>Economists such as <a href="/wiki/Burton_Malkiel" title="Burton Malkiel">Burton Malkiel</a> suggest that neither fundamental analysis nor <a href="/wiki/Technical_analysis" title="Technical analysis">technical analysis</a> is useful in outperforming the markets<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a>]</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_finance_topics#Valuation" title="List of finance topics" class="mw-redirect">Lists of valuation topics</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Stock_picking" title="Stock picking" class="mw-redirect">Stock picking</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Security_analysis" title="Security analysis">Security analysis</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Stock_selection_criterion" title="Stock selection criterion">Stock selection criterion</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Burr_Williams#Theory" title="John Burr Williams">John Burr Williams: Theory</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mosaic_theory_(investments)" title="Mosaic theory (investments)">Mosaic theory</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chepakovich_valuation_model" title="Chepakovich valuation model">Chepakovich valuation model</a></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span> <span class="mw-editsection">[<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: References">edit</a>]</span></h2>
